articles.title: Common asthma drug could prevent life-threatening allergic reactions
articles.summary: A single dose of the asthma medication zileuton stopped severe allergic reactions in mice by blocking food allergens from entering the bloodstream
articles.content:
A single dose of the asthma medication zileuton stopped severe allergic reactions in mice by blocking food allergens from entering the bloodstream

Stephanie Eisenbarth and Adam Williams prepping peanuts for allergy research in their lab Northwestern University

A common asthma medication has been shown to shield mice from anaphylaxis – a potentially fatal allergic reaction. The drug, called zileuton, has long been used to treat asthma and is now being trialled in humans as a possible treatment for severe allergic reactions to food.

Although many people have food allergies, it is difficult to predict an individual’s risk of anaphylaxis upon exposure to an allergen. Researchers have been working to understand why some people with positive blood tests for food allergens show no symptoms, while others experience severe, sometimes life-threatening reactions.

Advertisement

“Our goal is to find ways to make people with symptomatic food allergy tolerate exposure to allergens,” says Stephanie Eisenbarth at Northwestern University in Illinois.

Eisenbarth and her colleagues used groups of five to 10 mice that had been sensitised to peanut allergens such that they were expected to experience anaphylaxis with exposure to peanuts. Each mouse was given a single oral dose of zileuton about an hour before being fed peanut extract. A control group was not given the drug. Then the researchers watched the zileuton-dosed mice for signs of anaphylaxis, such as a drop in body temperature and increased heart rate, and found that nearly every zileuton-treated mouse remained symptom-free. The control group showed clear signs of anaphylaxis.

Most of the proteins we eat are broken down, but a few are actively transported across the gut and into the bloodstream intact. In severely allergic people, these trigger immune cells and cause anaphylaxis.

Free newsletter Sign up to Health Check Expert insight and news on scientific developments in health, nutrition and fitness, every Saturday. Sign up to newsletter

During an allergic reaction, the body also releases chemicals called leukotrienes. In the mice, the researchers found that leukotrienes control how many intact proteins pass through the gut. They also found that a gene called DPEP1 is involved in regulating the breakdown of leukotrienes.

One of zileuton’s effects is to block 5-lipoxygenase, an enzyme needed to produce leukotrienes. Giving the drug to the mice reduced leukotriene levels, allowing DPEP1 to keep the remaining leukotrienes in check, preventing allergen absorption and stalling anaphylaxis in sensitive mice. A single oral dose of zileuton led to a 95 per cent fall in anaphylaxis rates.

“We could take mice that normally respond to food allergens and make them unresponsive. We are now testing whether the same drug, which is already used clinically for asthma, can reduce allergen absorption in the gut in people with food allergy. If so, this could provide a treatment to prevent anaphylaxis,” says Eisenbarth.

Jorge Emiliano Gómez Medellín at the University of Chicago says this simple pill may provide significant relief from accidental exposure to the allergens. He adds that while zileuton may prevent the absorption of food allergens, it wouldn’t be able to alter a person’s sensitivity to them in the long term.

“Nonetheless, zileuton has the potential to become an important asset in our fight against food allergies,” he says.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a promising medical breakthrough where a common asthma drug shows potential to prevent life-threatening allergic reactions, which could significantly improve patient outcomes and quality of life.
articles.personality_title: Asthma drug shows promise in preventing severe allergic reactions
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Food allergies can cause dangerous reactions called anaphylaxis, but it is hard to predict who will have a severe response. Researchers want to find ways to help people tolerate allergens safely.

**What happened** – Scientists at Northwestern University tested the asthma drug zileuton on mice that were allergic to peanuts. They gave each mouse a single dose of the drug before feeding them peanut extract. Nearly all mice that received zileuton showed no signs of severe allergic reactions, while those without the drug did.

**Impact** – This finding is important because zileuton blocks allergens from entering the bloodstream, preventing the immune system from overreacting. Since zileuton is already an approved asthma medication, it could be developed faster as a treatment to protect people with food allergies from life-threatening reactions.

**What’s next step** – Researchers are now testing zileuton in human trials to see if it can safely prevent anaphylaxis in people with food allergies. Positive results could lead to a new way to manage severe allergies beyond avoiding allergens.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A common asthma drug, zileuton, has been shown to prevent severe allergic reactions in mice and is being studied as a potential treatment for food allergies in humans.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un médicament contre l'asthme pourrait prévenir les réactions allergiques graves
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les allergies alimentaires peuvent provoquer des réactions dangereuses appelées anaphylaxie, mais il est difficile de prédire qui aura une réaction sévère. Les chercheurs cherchent des moyens pour aider les personnes à tolérer les allergènes en toute sécurité.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des scientifiques de l'Université Northwestern ont testé le médicament contre l'asthme zileuton sur des souris allergiques aux arachides. Chaque souris a reçu une dose unique du médicament avant d'être exposée à un extrait d'arachide. Presque toutes les souris traitées avec zileuton n'ont montré aucun signe de réaction allergique grave, contrairement aux souris non traitées.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car zileuton bloque le passage des allergènes dans le sang, empêchant une réaction excessive du système immunitaire. Comme zileuton est déjà approuvé pour traiter l'asthme, il pourrait être développé plus rapidement comme traitement contre les réactions allergiques sévères.

**Prochaines étapes** – Les chercheurs testent maintenant zileuton chez l'humain pour vérifier s'il peut prévenir l'anaphylaxie chez les personnes allergiques. Des résultats positifs pourraient offrir une nouvelle manière de gérer les allergies sévères au-delà de l'évitement des allergènes.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Un médicament courant contre l'asthme, zileuton, a empêché des réactions allergiques sévères chez des souris et est étudié comme traitement potentiel des allergies alimentaires chez l'humain.
articles.personality_title_es: Medicamento para el asma muestra potencial para prevenir reacciones alérgicas graves
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Las alergias alimentarias pueden causar reacciones peligrosas llamadas anafilaxia, pero es difícil predecir quién tendrá una respuesta severa. Los investigadores buscan formas de ayudar a las personas a tolerar los alérgenos de manera segura.

**Qué ocurrió** – Científicos de la Universidad de Northwestern probaron el medicamento para el asma zileutón en ratones alérgicos al maní. Cada ratón recibió una dosis única del medicamento antes de ser alimentado con extracto de maní. Casi todos los ratones tratados con zileutón no mostraron signos de reacciones alérgicas graves, a diferencia del grupo control.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo es importante porque zileutón bloquea que los alérgenos entren al torrente sanguíneo, evitando una reacción exagerada del sistema inmunológico. Dado que zileutón ya está aprobado para tratar el asma, podría desarrollarse más rápido como tratamiento para proteger a personas con alergias alimentarias.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores están realizando ahora ensayos con humanos para evaluar si zileutón puede prevenir la anafilaxia en personas con alergias alimentarias. Resultados positivos podrían ofrecer una nueva forma de manejar alergias severas más allá de evitar alérgenos.

**Resumen en una frase** – Un medicamento común para el asma, zileutón, ha demostrado prevenir reacciones alérgicas severas en ratones y se estudia como posible tratamiento para alergias alimentarias en humanos.

articles.title: Laughter therapy really could boost your emotional well-being
articles.summary: Structured interventions that encourage a good giggle, whether they are laughter yoga or clown visits, could have health benefits
articles.content:
Structured interventions that encourage a good giggle, whether they are laughter yoga or clown visits, could have health benefits

Letting off steam at a laughter yoga session in Kolkata, India SOPA Images Limited/Alamy

It seems that laughter therapy is no joke. Structured interventions that aim to tickle our funny bone, like laughter yoga or hospital clowns, really do appear to reduce anxiety and improve life satisfaction.

Laughter, which is also common in non-human animals, is thought to enforce social connections and may even help babies acquire a sense of self. It has also been linked to improved health, with researchers finding that clown visits shorten the amount of time children spend in hospital.

Yelsyn-Mauricio Porras-Jiménez at the University of Jaén in Spain wanted to understand how we can better support people’s overall health – “not just the physical, but also the spiritual and emotional”, he says. “In the midst of searching for how to truly implement this comprehensive care, I came across laughter therapy.”

Porras-Jiménez and his colleagues carried out a meta-analysis of 33 studies done in the US, Europe, Asia and the Middle East. Many of the participants were nursing students, but they also included people undergoing end-of-life care, surgery or in vitro fertilisation, as well as individuals with depression or burnout.

All of the studies were made up of two groups: one received some form of laughter therapy – such as doing laughter yoga, which combines the physical activity with laughter exercises; being visited by a clown; watching funny films; or taking part in guided group laughing sessions – while the second group acted as the control, receiving either no intervention or carrying on with their usual care.

Free newsletter Sign up to Health Check Expert insight and news on scientific developments in health, nutrition and fitness, every Saturday. Sign up to newsletter

The researchers found that laughter therapy was consistently linked to reduced anxiety and improved life satisfaction. If you were to measure anxiety on a scale of 0 to 100, says Porras-Jiménez, the control group would have an average score of about 60, while the laughter therapy group would be 8 to 10 points lower. For life satisfaction, the control group would score about 50 and the laughter therapy group 10 to 12 points higher, he says.

But the participants couldn’t be blinded to the fact that they were receiving laughter therapy, so the findings might just be due to the placebo effect, says Sophie Scott at University College London.

But laughter does induce physiological changes that align with feeling less anxious, she says, including reductions in cortisol, a hormone produced in response to stress, and an uptick in endorphins, which act as neurotransmitters in the brain to create a feeling of well-being.

“It’s hard to say whether it’s because of the laughter or because of the social context in which you felt comfortable enough to laugh,” says Scott. “I suspect it’s both.”
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the positive impact of laughter therapy on emotional well-being, suggesting accessible and enjoyable interventions that can improve mental health. This is uplifting and offers hope for better emotional health through simple, engaging methods.
articles.personality_title: Laughter therapy shown to improve emotional well-being in diverse groups
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Laughter is a natural human behavior known to promote social connection and has been linked to health benefits. Researchers have explored ways to use laughter intentionally to support emotional and spiritual health, beyond just physical well-being.

**What happened** – A team led by Yelsyn-Mauricio Porras-Jiménez at the University of Jaén analyzed 33 studies from around the world involving people such as nursing students, patients undergoing medical treatments, and those facing mental health challenges. These studies tested laughter therapy methods like laughter yoga, clown visits, watching funny films, and guided group laughter sessions.

**Impact** – The analysis found that laughter therapy consistently helped reduce anxiety and improved satisfaction with life across different populations. For example, clown visits in hospitals were linked to shorter stays for children. This shows laughter therapy can be a practical, enjoyable way to enhance emotional health in various settings.

**What’s next step** – With evidence supporting laughter therapy's benefits, healthcare providers and wellness programs might consider incorporating these activities more widely. Further research could explore the best ways to tailor laughter interventions for specific groups and measure long-term effects.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Structured laughter therapy offers a simple and effective way to boost emotional well-being across diverse groups and health conditions.
articles.personality_title_fr: La thérapie par le rire améliore le bien-être émotionnel selon une étude internationale
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le rire est un comportement humain naturel qui favorise les liens sociaux et est associé à des bienfaits pour la santé. Des chercheurs ont étudié comment utiliser le rire de façon intentionnelle pour soutenir la santé émotionnelle et spirituelle, au-delà de la santé physique.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une équipe dirigée par Yelsyn-Mauricio Porras-Jiménez de l’Université de Jaén a analysé 33 études réalisées dans le monde entier, impliquant des étudiants en soins infirmiers, des patients en traitement médical et des personnes souffrant de troubles mentaux. Ces études ont testé des méthodes de thérapie par le rire comme le yoga du rire, les visites de clowns, les films comiques et les séances de rire en groupe.

**Impact** – L’analyse a montré que la thérapie par le rire aide à réduire l’anxiété et améliore la satisfaction de vie dans différents groupes. Par exemple, les visites de clowns à l’hôpital ont contribué à réduire la durée d’hospitalisation des enfants. Cela démontre que la thérapie par le rire est une façon pratique et agréable d’améliorer la santé émotionnelle.

**Prochaine étape** – Avec ces preuves, les professionnels de santé et les programmes de bien-être pourraient intégrer ces activités plus largement. De nouvelles recherches pourraient explorer comment adapter ces interventions à différents publics et évaluer leurs effets à long terme.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La thérapie par le rire structurée est un moyen simple et efficace d’améliorer le bien-être émotionnel dans divers groupes et conditions de santé.
articles.personality_title_es: La terapia de la risa mejora el bienestar emocional según un análisis global
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La risa es un comportamiento humano natural que fomenta las conexiones sociales y está vinculada a beneficios para la salud. Investigadores han estudiado cómo usar la risa de manera intencional para apoyar la salud emocional y espiritual, además de la física.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo liderado por Yelsyn-Mauricio Porras-Jiménez de la Universidad de Jaén analizó 33 estudios de todo el mundo con estudiantes de enfermería, pacientes en tratamientos médicos y personas con problemas de salud mental. Estos estudios probaron terapias de risa como yoga de la risa, visitas de payasos, películas cómicas y sesiones grupales de risa guiada.

**Impacto** – El análisis encontró que la terapia de la risa redujo consistentemente la ansiedad y mejoró la satisfacción con la vida en diferentes grupos. Por ejemplo, las visitas de payasos en hospitales acortaron la estancia de niños. Esto demuestra que la terapia de la risa es un método práctico y agradable para mejorar la salud emocional.

**Próximo paso** – Con estas evidencias, los proveedores de salud y programas de bienestar podrían incorporar estas actividades más comúnmente. Más investigaciones pueden explorar cómo adaptar la terapia de risa a grupos específicos y evaluar sus efectos a largo plazo.

**Mensaje en una frase** – La terapia estructurada de la risa ofrece una forma sencilla y efectiva de mejorar el bienestar emocional en diversos grupos y condiciones de salud.
